body: I have no idea about your environment. But if you are using docker, the timeout is determined by `timeout` parameter in [run.sh](https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/blob/master/tools/run.sh).

I've got a heroku deployment running with a project that has ~8000 classification documents that I'm trying to export as well. It's throwing a "Request timeout" / status 503  for  path="/v1/projects/1/docs/download?q=csv"  with the timeout at 30001ms.  It looks like Heroku sets a pretty hard cap on 30 seconds per request https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/request-timeout

@Hironsan Do we want to offload the data export to a queue like Celery? For example, we could use an approach like this:

![Asynchronous data export approach](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1086421/60603956-b6d27300-9d84-11e9-9699-7dc425cd7bdb.png)

Also having trouble importing/exporting data due to timeout on Heroku.  I can get around the issue with importing by breaking up my data into multiple files, but can't export.

I'm not familiar with vue or django, if no one comes up with a solution I may have to find a way to export the data directly from postgresql

@echan00 Yep I ended up just exporting from postgresql, but I also might try temporarily bumping the Heroku dyno up a tier or two just to see if the more powerful ones can complete the export in time.
@john-dugan thanks would you mind sharing your postgresql export code?

Sure thing - it by no means was meant to resemble the Doccano export format, just something hacked together that was usable for my case (on the older schema fyi) 

```
SELECT annotation.id, annotation.document_id, annotation.label_id, annotation.user_id, documents.id, documents.text, documents.meta FROM server_documentannotation annotation    INNER JOIN server_document documents ON annotation.document_id = documents.id WHERE annotation.label_id in (3,4,5) ORDER BY documents.id ASC
```

issue.title: Feature Request: Upload/Download data from Cloud Storage directly

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Recently, many user will have their data on cloud storage like S3/GCS etc.

For that reason, it'll be good to upload data from cloud storage directly, and also save annotated data to it. If this feature implemented, there are no need to have the data on local.

issue.title: Enhancement/Export data via Celery

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Currently doccano's data export happens within the HTTP request/response cycle. However when the exported datasets are large, the export can take some time to run which often leads to a HTTP timeout. To fix this problem, this pull request moves the data export into a background worker implemented with Celery.

For production setups, the Celery worker can be run as a stand-alone container and the Django server can communicate to the worker via an external queue such as RabbitMQ (this is demonstrated in docker-compose.yml). However, to also keep offering a simple one click deployment model, this pull request additionally implements running both the Django server and the Celery worker inside of the same Docker container, communicating via the local SQLite database.

In the future, other long-running operations (e.g. data import) could also be moved to Celery to improve performance.

Resolves https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/issues/241

body:
> Sure thing - it by no means was meant to resemble the Doccano export format, just something hacked together that was usable for my case (on the older schema fyi)
> 
> ```
> SELECT annotation.id, annotation.document_id, annotation.label_id, annotation.user_id, documents.id, documents.text, documents.meta FROM server_documentannotation annotation    INNER JOIN server_document documents ON annotation.document_id = documents.id WHERE annotation.label_id in (3,4,5) ORDER BY documents.id ASC
> ```

I wonder where and how should I execute this SQL command?
